entry.title: Leistungen für Wasser- und Gaszählerwechsel
entry.content:
Wasser- und Gaszählerwechgsel zählt seit mehr als 20 Jahren zu unserem Leistungskatalog.

Für uns gehört zum Zählerwechsel aber mehr als nur der turnusmäßige Austausch der Zähler. Im Folgenden finden sie unser komplettes Angebot an Dienstleistungen vom Anschreiben des Kunden bis zur Abrechnung mit dem Versorger.
entry.summary: Wasser- und Gaszählerwechgsel zählt seit mehr als 20 Jahren zu unserem Leistungskatalog.

entry.title: Kunden und Partner in der Wasserhygiene

link.title: Kunden und Partner in der Wasserhygiene

entry.content:
Zu unseren zufriedenen und langjährigen Kunden zählen wir zahlreiche Wasserversorger und Stadtwerke im gesamten Nordeutschen Raum.

Unsere Werte: Sauberkeit, Zuverlässigkeit und Umsichtigkeit

Langjährige Partnerschaft Produkte, Beratung und Leistung aus einer Hand

In diesem Bereich arbeiten wir seit mehr als 10 Jahren eng mit der Carela Gruppe zusammen, um die Qualität unseres Trinkwassers zu sichern und zu erhalten.
entry.summary: Zu unseren zufriedenen und langjährigen Kunden zählen wir zahlreiche Wasserversorger und Stadtwerke im gesamten Nordeutschen Raum.

entry.title: Leistungen rund um Trinkwasser und -behälter
entry.content:
Wasser ist ein Naturprodukt und das soll es auch bleiben.

Trinkwasserbehälter

Reinigung und Desinfektion von Trinkwasserbehältern der kommunalen und industriellen Wasserversorgung gemäß den Vorgabe aus DVGW und TrinkwV.

Rohrleitungen

Von Hausleitungen bis hin zu industriellen Leitungssystemen, reinigen und desinfizieren wir gegen mineralische Verunreinigungen wie Kalk oder Mangan oder gegen biologische Verunreinigungen wie Legionellen oder E-Koli Bakterien.

akkreditierte Probenentnahme & -analyse

Für uns ist es selbstverständlich das Sauberkeit von Trinkwasser immer auch Bewiesen werden muss. Deshalb nehmen wir Proben und lassen diese bei akkreditierten Instituten analysieren.
entry.summary: Wasser ist ein Naturprodukt und das soll es auch bleiben.

entry.title: MathJax Example
entry.content:
MathJax is a simple way of including Tex/LaTex/MathML based mathematics in HTML webpages. To get up and running you need to include the MathJax script in the header of your github pages page, and then write some maths. For LaTex, there are two delimiters you need to know about, one for block or displayed mathematics \[ ... \], and the other for inline mathematics \( ... \).

Usage

To enable MathJax support be sure Kramdown is your Markdown flavor of choice and MathJax is set to true in your _config.yml file.

markdown: kramdown
mathjax: true

Here is an example MathJax inline rendering \\( 1/x^{2} \\), and here is a block rendering: 
\\[ \frac{1}{n^{2}} \\]

Here is an example MathJax inline rendering \( 1/x^{2} \), and here is a block rendering: \[ \frac{1}{n^{2}} \]

The only thing to look out for is the escaping of the backslash when using markdown, so the delimiters become \\[ ... \\] and \\( ... \\) for inline and block maths respectively.
entry.summary: MathJax is a simple way of including Tex/LaTex/MathML based mathematics in HTML webpages. To get up and running you need to include the MathJax script in the header of your github pages page, and then write some maths. For LaTex, there are two delimiters you need to know about, one for block or displayed mathematics \[ ... \], and the other for inline mathematics \( ... \).

entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory - edit this post and re-build (or run with the -w switch) to see your changes! To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention: YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext.

Sample Heading

Sample Heading 2

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

def print_hi(name)
  puts "Hi, #{name}"
end
print_hi('Tom')
#=> prints 'Hi, Tom' to STDOUT.

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory - edit this post and re-build (or run with the -w switch) to see your changes! To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention: YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext.

entry.title: Override Author Byline Test Post
entry.content:
For those of you who may have content written by multiple authors on your site you can now assign different authors to each post if desired.

Previously the theme used a global author for the entire site and those attributes would be used in all bylines, social networking links, Twitter Card attribution, and Google Authorship. These owner variables were defined in config.yml

Start by modifying or creating a new authors.yml file in the _data folder and add your authors using the following format.

# Authors

billy_rick:
  name: Billy Rick
  web: http://thewhip.com
  email: billy@rick.com
  bio: "What do you want, jewels? I am a very extravagant man."
  avatar: bio-photo-2.jpg
  twitter: extravagantman
  google:
    plus: BillyRick

cornelius_fiddlebone:
  name: Cornelius Fiddlebone
  email: cornelius@thewhip.com
  bio: "I ordered what?"
  avatar: bio-photo.jpg
  twitter: rhymeswithsackit
  google:
    plus: CorneliusFiddlebone

To assign Billy Rick as an author for our post. You’d add the following YAML front matter to a post:

author: billy_rick
entry.summary: An article to test overriding the default site author.

entry.title: Syntax Highlighting Post
entry.content:
Syntax highlighting is a feature that displays source code, in different colors and fonts according to the category of terms. This feature facilitates writing in a structured language such as a programming language or a markup language as both structures and syntax errors are visually distinct. Highlighting does not affect the meaning of the text itself; it is intended only for human readers.1

Highlighted Code Blocks

To modify styling and highlight colors edit /_sass/_syntax.scss.

#container {
  float: left;
  margin: 0 -240px 0 0;
  width: 100%;
}


<nav class="pagination" role="navigation">
    {% if page.previous %}
        <a href="{{ site.url }}{{ page.previous.url }}" class="btn" title="{{ page.previous.title }}">Previous article</a>
    {% endif %}
    {% if page.next %}
        <a href="{{ site.url }}{{ page.next.url }}" class="btn" title="{{ page.next.title }}">Next article</a>
    {% endif %}
</nav><!-- /.pagination -->


module Jekyll
  class TagIndex < Page
    def initialize(site, base, dir, tag)
      @site = site
      @base = base
      @dir = dir
      @name = 'index.html'
      self.process(@name)
      self.read_yaml(File.join(base, '_layouts'), 'tag_index.html')
      self.data['tag'] = tag
      tag_title_prefix = site.config['tag_title_prefix'] || 'Tagged: '
      tag_title_suffix = site.config['tag_title_suffix'] || '–'
      self.data['title'] = "#{tag_title_prefix}#{tag}"
      self.data['description'] = "An archive of posts tagged #{tag}."
    end
  end
end

Standard Code Block

<nav class="pagination" role="navigation">
    {% if page.previous %}
        <a href="{{ site.url }}{{ page.previous.url }}" class="btn" title="{{ page.previous.title }}">Previous article</a>
    {% endif %}
    {% if page.next %}
        <a href="{{ site.url }}{{ page.next.url }}" class="btn" title="{{ page.next.title }}">Next article</a>
    {% endif %}
</nav><!-- /.pagination -->

Fenced Code Blocks

#container {
    float: left;
    margin: 0 -240px 0 0;
    width: 100%;
}

<nav class="pagination" role="navigation">
    {% if page.previous %}
        <a href="{{ site.url }}{{ page.previous.url }}" class="btn" title="{{ page.previous.title }}">Previous article</a>
    {% endif %}
    {% if page.next %}
        <a href="{{ site.url }}{{ page.next.url }}" class="btn" title="{{ page.next.title }}">Next article</a>
    {% endif %}
</nav><!-- /.pagination -->

module Jekyll
  class TagIndex < Page
    def initialize(site, base, dir, tag)
      @site = site
      @base = base
      @dir = dir
      @name = 'index.html'
      self.process(@name)
      self.read_yaml(File.join(base, '_layouts'), 'tag_index.html')
      self.data['tag'] = tag
      tag_title_prefix = site.config['tag_title_prefix'] || 'Tagged: '
      tag_title_suffix = site.config['tag_title_suffix'] || '–'
      self.data['title'] = "#{tag_title_prefix}#{tag}"
      self.data['description'] = "An archive of posts tagged #{tag}."
    end
  end
end

  1. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntax_highlighting ↩
entry.summary: Demo post displaying the various ways of highlighting code in Markdown.

entry.title: A Post with a Video
entry.content:
Video embeds are responsive and scale with the width of the main content block with the help of FitVids.

<iframe width="560" height="315" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/PWf4WUoMXwg" frameborder="0"> </iframe>

And here’s a Vimeo embed for testing purposes.
entry.summary: Custom written post descriptions are the way to go... if you're not lazy.
